body: This is merged as the PR contains some fix of the current breaking changes in master
Can we directly bake this into AlphaEqual of types?

Agreed with @tqchen, that check could be moved into the top-level AlphaEqual() function. However, adding tests for nulls where nulls are allowed is good (we should be diligent in documenting which fields are allowed to be null!)
This looks really cool, well done @liangfu.
Thanks @slyubomirsky @siju-samuel , this is now merged

@RichardFido The example doesn't work because of the rigid structure of how bounds are deduced for the conditionals. I do not understand that portion of the code. There is an easy workaround for now.

~~~
Line causing issue - with ib.if_scope(ib.likely(head1*loop1 < tile - head2)):
Replace  - with ib.if_scope(ib.likely(head1*loop1 + head2 < tile)):
~~~

If the constant is not present on the right side alone, then the deduce_bound function does not work correctly. Solving for any combination of conditions will require decent changes in deduce_bounds functions or Simplify pass. I do not plan to work on that in this PR.
thanks, got it working with llvm trunk.

> Hi, according the [community issue convention](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/f721a645cd77661a8284559d676ef20f91eaa771/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md), it's recommended to post to https://discuss.tvm.ai first. The community will help investigate and convert it into an actionable item laster as a github issue. And it's also very helpful to provide the exact command you use that cause the error and provide as much error log as possible.

OK,thanks.

argmax and argmin support is deleted.
Output dtype of these are fp32 in MXNet.
However, these are int32 in NNVM, Tensorflow, coreml and onnx.

> I think you are using CPU backends.
> 
> Currently, we always create an intermediate buffer for dilation (compute_root). We can use compute_inline + unroll to eliminate multiplications of zeros and large intermediate buffers. Significant performance gain can be obtained here.

I am using GPU backend. I don't quite understand how compute_inline + unroll can solve this problem.
Do you have sample code? If yes, Maybe I can try it in my model to see the performance gain.
Thank you for adding tests. If the point you have pointed out is a testing problem for argmin and argmax, #1908 may be able to fix it.

The lint environment is very version dependent, both in terms of python version and pylint version. To reproduce the lint on CI exactly, you can use 

docker/bash.sh tvmai/ci-lint ./tests/scripts/task_lint.sh
Please use https://discuss.tvm.ai/ on installation questions. In your case, the reason is that tvm OpenGL depends on glfw3 but it cannot find it in your system cmake.

@siju-samuel @yzhliu Welcome for review.

I am afraid that after this PR, users will see too many warning messages "Cannot find a config for workload xxx, A fallback configuration is used..." when they try CPU demos.
We should not disable this warning because it is critical for people who care about performance.
How can we deal with this in the long run?

One quick fix is to upload some tuned results for common networks to [TopHub](https://github.com/uwsampl/tvm-distro).
Steps:
1. upstream a 'llvm_v0.01.log' to https://github.com/uwsampl/tvm-distro/tree/master/tophub
2. add a line 
```python
'llvm': "v0.01",
```
to https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/dc996e451a3fee9dffefc31b652b6e85a72cb041/python/tvm/autotvm/tophub.py#L22-L26

Then tvm will download pre-tuned configs when compiling models.

I think adding configs to TopHub for x86 is a good idea.
Do we currently have a way of specifying which models of x86 CPUs should share configs? There are likely to be x86 users with _many_ different CPU models in the long run.
cc @masahi @sgrechanik-h @Huyuwei @FrozenGene welcome to review

But, If argmin and argmax return the indices as float32 in mxnet, we would need to discuss how to support it. 
BTW, In this PR, do you intend to support only operators excluding argmin and argmax?
@yzhliu @kazum could you please have a look at this PR. TIA

I did some experiments on AWS EC2 machines. Currently the only flag differentiating x86 CPU models is the instruction set. C5 and M5 which have avx512 can share schedules, while C4 and M4 with AVX2 can share schedules. Later we can identify more specs, and have a guideline for developer to choose pre-tuned schedules.

Now we use `-model` in target to match the log. We record model in the pre-tuned log.

For example, for NVIDIA GPU, the targets in the log contain `cuda -model=1080ti`, `cuda -model=titanx`.
Then users specify model when they create the target.

https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/4c13ee22bf8e9f693176418ee77f65890327ec3e/apps/benchmark/gpu_imagenet_bench.py#L41

> Now we use `-model` in target to match the log. We record model in the pre-tuned log.
> 
> For example, for NVIDIA GPU, the targets in the log contain `cuda -model=1080ti`, `cuda -model=titanx`.
> Then users specify model when they create the target.
> 
> [tvm/apps/benchmark/gpu_imagenet_bench.py](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/4c13ee22bf8e9f693176418ee77f65890327ec3e/apps/benchmark/gpu_imagenet_bench.py#L41)
> 
> Line 41 in [4c13ee2](/dmlc/tvm/commit/4c13ee22bf8e9f693176418ee77f65890327ec3e)
>  target = tvm.target.create('%s -model=%s' % (args.target, args.model))

Model is interesting as there are currently a few different ways of specifying the "model" of x86: uarch (skylake-avx512 vs. avx2, ...), actual model (4790K vs. 8700K vs. 8180, ...), and instances (c5 vs. m4, ...). But I think we can defer solving this problem at least for a little while, even if we have to rely on a few profile runs before execusion; we can just do what cuDNN does here and try out a few schedules if the user does not know how/want to specify their exact model.

close by #1921
@imorinaga  yes, I'd suggest changing the title.
Funny, it is `np.isclose` which has the default value of `atol=1e-08`. In contrast, `np.testing.assert_allclose` uses default `atol=0`

As @kevinthesun and I discussed in #1585, there is a known issue of measurement on c5.9xlarge, which makes measurement results unreliable.

At that time I provided a hack to fix it. But that is not upstreamed. 
I also found this issue on arm cpu.

Here I provide another easier hack to fix this. It works for arm cpu.  @kevinthesun Can you verify it on c5.9xlarge instance? If it works, we can make a PR.

```diff
diff --git a/python/tvm/autotvm/measure/measure_methods.py b/python/tvm/autotvm/measure/measure_methods.py
index ec3eb7e..f16064b 100644
--- a/python/tvm/autotvm/measure/measure_methods.py
+++ b/python/tvm/autotvm/measure/measure_methods.py
@@ -460,7 +460,11 @@ def run_through_rpc(measure_input, build_result,
         if ref_input:
             args = [nd.array(x, ctx=ctx) for x in ref_input]
         else:
+            # create empty arrays on the remote device and copy them once.
+            # This can avoid some memory issues that make the measurment unreliable
             args = [nd.empty(x[0], dtype=x[1], ctx=ctx) for x in build_result.arg_info]
+            args = [nd.array(x, ctx=ctx) for x in args]
+            ctx.sync()
 
         costs = time_f(*args).results
         if len(costs) > 2:  # remove largest and smallest value to reduce variance

```
@junrushao1994 & @tqchen have a look again.
@tqchen can you give some review?
can we just use [numpy.allclose](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.15.1/reference/generated/numpy.allclose.html)?

> can we just use [numpy.allclose](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.15.1/reference/generated/numpy.allclose.html)?

Do you mean you'd like to replace `np.testing.assert_allclose(..,atol=1e-8)` with `assert np.allclose(..), "Some message"` ? AFAIK, semantics is the same, but the current version already includes meaningful message.

--
Also let me stress, that by introducing our own `assert_allclose` we cut the dependency on numpy implementation, which may not be optimal for tvm and may change from version to version.

Some comments:

- Let us move langref/relay/*.rst to langref/relay_*.rst, as there won't be a lot language reference and it reduces one level of indirection.
- When writing IR code, maybe we want to think about consistency with the text format.
- Incorporate some of our discussions of graph mode vs let binding with text format will really help explain the concept

This PR is feature complete, and we'd like to push it soon. We'd also like to **freeze the keywords and the overall look-and-feel of the text format** in this PR, so **now is a great time to provide feedback** about the design choices. Keep in mind that the ANTLR grammar is a superset of the syntax we accept. `parser.py` does some checks to enforce additional rules, but is able to provide better error messages than ANTLR can.

### Loose Ends

There are some elements of the text format that didn't make it into this PR. See #1935 for details.
Thanks @joshpoll @slyubomirsky , this is merged
cc @jroesch @MarisaKirisame @yuruofeifei @grwlf @nhynes
Can we move general grammar choice discussion to https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/1782 (I copied the keyword proposal to the beginning of the RFC)
cc @junrushao1994 @dmlc/tvm-team @jroesch @MarisaKirisame @yuruofeifei @grwlf please comment on the choices of keywords in the text format. (see beginning of the post)

I think one general question we want to ask when deciding keyword is consistency, and whether we want to enforce some of these. Note that being consistent with common choices will always reduce the mind burden of users, and we should try to do so when possible

-  Consistency with python style
  - boolean ```true/false```  vs ```True/False```
  - tuple:  ```(1)``` vs ```(1,)```
- Whether we support alternative printing of list
  - e.g. ```axis=[1,2]``` or should we always print Array<IndexExpr> as ```axis=(1,2)```    
- Consistency with numpy base type convention(and the printing output of tvm types)
    - e,g. float32, bool vs Float32, Bool
    - I can understand one possible reason to go for Float32 is that it really means ```Tensor[(), float32] ```, but do we need to make such distinguishment or not
- Consistent with common choices of existing languages
   - e.g. use of ```->``` vs ```=>```
      - Rust: fn(args) -> return_type 
      - Swift func(args)-> return_type
- How to express common constant with type information
   - example proposal:
      - 1 -> const(1, int32)
      - 1.0f  -> const(1, float32)
      - float64(1) -> const(1, float64)
